Double jeopardy means that a person may not be tried more than once for the same crime. (ie if you are charged with murder, found innocent, you cannot be charged again for the same murder yet again, despite the finding of new evidence)
 That being said, the reason for the double jeopardy laws is simply because once a person is tried, has their day in court and are found to be innocent, they are innocent. Our court system was set up to avoid abuses. If say a law enforcement officer didn't like you because you had a pink car, and that car was missing a muffler, and every day it woke them up at 4 am when you started it by backfiring. You were thought to have been involved in a breaking and entering during the nighttime with the intent to commit a felony. You were arrested, tried, found innocent. The next day if the double jeopardy laws were not in place they could arrest you again, have you tried again, have you found innocent again, and this could continue until you were drained of all of your finances and had to finally sell the pink car. 
 It would be a never ending cycle. This is why each person is given their day in court, the burden of proof is on the prosecution, and they must prove beynd a reasonable doubt that you committed that crime.

Unless the DA has enough evidence for them to believe they can win the case, they won't try it. They know full well that double jeopardy laws are in place, they have one shot to get it right. They aren't going to roll the dice if the investigation isn't finished. Sometimes this means a murder may be in the unsolved files for a long time, but once they have that information the case will go forward. 
 For example, a breaking and entering during the nighttime with the intent to commit a felony (larceny over $250) occured 2 years ago. The facts at hand presented themselves so that there were a few suspects, one better than the others. There wasn't enough evidence for the case to go to trial. Last week a tip came in, case broke wide open and I expect formal charges to go forward within the next two weeks. 
 Sometimes it takes time, it's not an automatic sort of tv show type thing. It doesn't work that way. The more thorough a criminal, the more thorough the invest and the longer it can take. They aren't going to to go to trial unless they believe they can get a ruling of guilty. 
 Additionally, our justice system was set up for one purpose. Better 1,000 guilty men go free, lest one innocent man be convicted. Hence the double jeopardy laws. Sometimes it does happen, a guilty man goes free and he laughs all the way, but I believe more often than not we get our man.
